turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You might tell a fellow things, 'specially if the fellow's your brother, seems to me.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Like why you're buyin' a whole slew of 30 30 shells all of a sudden.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I don't want to run short.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You never said this Lednov's name before, that I can remember.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No call to. That jail looked pretty solid to me.  How's she feel?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Nice.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: But it's leaded up and anyway a 22's no good for real huntin'. You shoot a man with a 22 and where are you?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: The thing to do is stick to rabbits.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What was he in jail for?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You sure worry that bone. He killed a fellow.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: In a fight?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: The other fellow wasn't even lookin'.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: This is an awful nice gun.  Certainly come in handy when there's men around who shoot people that aren't lookin'.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You must be plenty worried about Lednov sneakin' up on us.  Think he will?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: At the ranch maybe?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Maybe at the ranch. Maybe sooner than that.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Do you have to be so close-mouthed? I'm your brother. And I'm ridin' with you. Remember?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: All right. I'll tell you.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: That's Lednov!  We come along here.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: And meet him there.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Unless the sheriff gets too close and he holes up.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Sure a lot of guys lookin' for Lednov.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Yeah -- and Lednov's only lookin' for one man. Me.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: He doesn't like me. What you eatin'?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Lednov.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: They sure must have been travelin'. This keeps up we can start a store.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Things get tough next winter, you'll have somethin' to wear.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I've got eleven horses.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Morgan blood. The beat in Nevada. Clay and me have a place on the Toulomne River. We're going to raise horses like these.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Where'd they go?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Swimming.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: There was only three of them at first. I guess I lost my head.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: How'd you happen to miss?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: They were quite a ways off and the wind was blowin'. I didn't have them to aim.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Good thing you didn't.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: A man can't help gettin' excited once in a while.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: That's right, Steve.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Can I have my gun back?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Sure. You'll find it under the wagon seat. Like I said before, a twenty- two's more your size.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It's all right with me if she teaches you, but I don't want you forgettin' your job.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I won't again.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Okeh, I was wrong. But you can't expect a fellow who never saw Lednov and never heard his name until a while ago to do too much worryin'. You've been sorta close mouthed about him.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I guess I have. You were pretty little when they locked him up. I don't suppose you even remember that time I was gone two months.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Sure I remember. You went to Mexico lookin' for cattle.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You remember Jeff Rawson? -- We used to go fishing and hunting with him when you were so high.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Sure I do. Went off down to Mexico or something...

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: That's what I told you then. Only he didn't. Lednov killed him.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Oh... that's the time you went away.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I caught up with Lednov in Nogales. He didn't like the idea of comin' back across the border but he came. I turned him over to the sheriff and -- that's the story.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Maybe you shoulda killed him.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Maybe I should. But I was never much on killin'. Anyway, he moved too quick and I just got him through the shoulder.  Looks pretty peaceful up ahead.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Yeah, it does.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: But you never can tell. Why don't you get that new rifle out of the wagon?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Leaving them here when we could just as well take them. We got plenty of room in the wagon. And -- and -- they cook and drive the mules. They don't bother anybody.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Finished, son?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: There's only two of them now.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Don't go arguing with your teacher.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I'm not, but there's some of it I don't see any sense to.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: There's a lot of things I don't see any sense to. But make up your mind. Learn to read or --  -- go back and watch the horses.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Want the wagon unloaded, Clay?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Just the grub box and bed rolls.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I didn't stop to think, Clay.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You better start.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: All right, I hurt your feelings. But you know better than to go lightin' fires.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: That ain't why. I just figure it's about time to start runnin' my own life.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Come on. We got a couple hours to eat and get some sleep.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I'll eat when I'm good and ready.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Kind of feeling your oats this morning. I haven't laid a hand on you for quite a while, but that doesn't mean you're too old.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What makes you think you're so almighty? Telling people what to do and how to act when you don't even know how yourself.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Go on, hit me.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Sit down and eat. Till I say the word, you're doing what you're told.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You oughta say you're sorry -- that's what you oughta do.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You keep your nose out of my life, young fella.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Maybe I haven't lived as long as you have, but I know a sight more about people and I wouldn't talk to a mule like you talked to her and, if I did, I'd say how sorry I was. I'd be man enough to do that.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I said keep your nose out of my life. No kid is going to tell me how to run it.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You think you're so slmighty -- smart -- Who are you to sit up there and say nobody's good enough for you, like you said yesterday -- just because a man kisses a woman --

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You know what she asked me?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I don't care what she asked you.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: She told me not to fight with you anymore. She said it wasn't your fault, but -- I figure different...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: It is so your fault and... and I guess maybe when we hit the ranch... you andme better...

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You want to split up? --

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Half of them are mine.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You'll get your share. Go on. I don't want you around.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What did you come back for?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Like I told you, half those horses are mine. I'm makin' sure they get to the ranch safe. So let's quit arguing and do whatever you figure on doin'.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Is that the only reason you came back?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Sure. What other reason would there be?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I just wondered. Let's go.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: How's that?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Kind of sore.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You'll live.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Guess maybe I'm old enough to hold my own in a fight, huh?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Yeah -- but don't make a habit of it.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: So -- maybe I'm old enough to tell you how to run your life?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I guess so -- but don't make a habit of it.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Well, then, I know it takes three -- four weeks for you to come round to admit when you're wrong... But by that time she's liable to be in China...

turns.speaker: WYATT
turns.text: You can light the lamp.  I'm sure glad it's you. We were afraid those killers might come back.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Three men on matched roans?

turns.speaker: WYATT
turns.text: Yeah, how did you know?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: The whole state's lookin' for 'em.  And they're lookin' for me.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm sorry about this, Mr. Wyatt. I didn't know who she was.

turns.speaker: WYATT
turns.text: All right, you didn't know.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I can't take her with me.

turns.speaker: WYATT
turns.text: Nobody asked you to.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You're not bein' quite fair.

turns.speaker: WYATT
turns.text: What's there to be fair about?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm sorry about this, Mr. Wyatt. I didn't know you had a daughter.

turns.speaker: WYATT
turns.text: All right, you didn't know.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I can't take her with me.

turns.speaker: WYATT
turns.text: Nobody asked you to.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You're not bein' quite fair.

turns.speaker: WYATT
turns.text: What's there to be fair about?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You can't stay here. There's snakes and it's cold and you'll just get sicker.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I don't care.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Suppose that Lednov was to have found you, instead of me. Why you wouldn't have had a chance.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I said I didn't care.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What's botherin' you, anyway?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Runnin' off and worryin' people. Makin' it tougher on Clay than it is already.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Don't ask me because I won't tell you! I won't tell anybody! Go away!

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Don't act so -- crazy.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I'm sorry. Let's go.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: That's a good girl.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Helen -- why don't you and Mary go on with Clay?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: He won't take us.  Don't you want us around?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Of course I do -- but it'd be better for you -- and the house is kind of small --

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: If you're worried about Mary and me talkin' too much, don't. No matter how many questions your old man asks. We know how to keep our mouths shut.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: It isn't that --

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Don't talk -- eat -- we want to get you well quick as we can so we can all get out of here.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: But I want to stay.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Drink this and stop being silly. Why would anyone want to live in this place. You might as well be dead and buried. Nothing to do but look at mountains. In a week you'd be talking to yourself.  Maybe that's what got you started in the first place.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I'm not going anywhere. I'm staying here where I belong.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Not if I know Mary. When she rides into Sonora, you'll be with her. And mighty glad to be there after this. I don't see how you stood it as long as you did.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Stop it -- stop it.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Darling -- now I've got you all upset.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Go away -- please.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: That's right -- you go back to sleep. Tomorrow when you feel better things will look a whole lot different. Don't you worry about anything -- Mary's going to talk things over with your folks --

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: She mustn't -- don't you let her --

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: There, there. Don't you upset yourself --

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: If she says anything to them I'll kill her.

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: You got no business snoopin' around --

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Me snoopin'? I came down here to take a bath.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: That something I shouldn't see?

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: No. But it's mine and I didn't want anyone foolin' with it.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: Just a thing I was workin' on.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: The way you act, it must be something pretty secret.

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: Go on. Take your bath. I'll beat it.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You wouldn't have a smoke on you, would you?

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: That sure smells good.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I like it.

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: Up here in the hills, a man gets a hankering to smell powder.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Then why stay in the hills.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You're sure there's more where this came from?

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: Plenty more.  And somewhere up there's the lode, the rock rotten with it.

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: I figure we'll get along just fine.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Well cheer, why don't you? No more responsibilities, Mary. Marcia -- Elaine -- me -- all taken care of. Down there feeding horses and raising kids, you won't have a thing to worry about.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: I saw your fire and dropped by to say hello.

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: Well, say it.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: What's the matter -- restless?

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: Yes, people make me restless.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: Even women?

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: There aren't any women here.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: I suppose that's your wagon in the river.

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: Some people who went by this way lost it.  Two men and some women. They packed their stuff on horses and went on.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: And you're all alone.

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: Suppose I take a look.

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: When I ask questions, I like to hear answers.

turns.speaker: FOWLER
turns.text: They went on like I told you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Until you came along we were going to Sonora.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What do you know about that. Did you sell your place?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Not exactly. They decided gambling and dancing were bad for people.  Can I make it?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Depends on how good you drive.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: There you are. Now take it easy and you'll be all right.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thank you, Mr. Graham.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Aspen doesn't want us Mr. Graham. They threw us out.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: They shouldn't have done that.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We tried to point that out. But there were some pretty nosey citizens who wouldn't listen to reason. They said Aspen had outgrown us. It's all right to play poker in your own home but not in a saloon.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I knew something would happen when they started puttin' up fences and passin' laws.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Goodbye and thanks.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't like to see you go.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Maybe you're going about this all wrong. Why not try telling him we'll do the cookin' and mendin' and washin' for him. That usually works.  Yeah, but suppose he took us up on it. Where would we be?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Maybe in Sonora.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You think that's all we busted -- You should see...

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Now where's she goin'? --

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: With a milk pail in one hand and a marriage license in the other.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why didn't you say you wanted to get married back in Aspen. I told the man in Sonora there were four of us. If only three show up, he might call the whole deal off. We've got to stick together. Like we've always done.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: It isn't like this was the first place we were ever thrown out of.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That's not what's worryin' me. Why didn't she tell us? Maybe we could have done somethin' -- gone somewhere else -- puttin' a poor sick kid through this --

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Quit worryin' about Elaine.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I tried my best, but these things take time.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: And we're running out of that.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: There's still tomorrow morning.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: How long do you think we'll have to stay here?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Until Pa gets around to driving us to Minden.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: We don't want to go there.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No we don't. But that's where we're going. From Minden we take a stage to Reno, then another one over to Auburn and another one to Placerville. Then it's a day's trip to Sonora.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Clay could save us an awful lot of time.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He certainly could. About a month.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: What are you waiting for? Do something.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You're not giving up?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: How many ways can a man say no.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Maybe I better start working on him.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You'd think he'd do it for Elaine's sake, at least...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Go on. Have another try at him.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What's the use.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Please. Maybe he'll take a good look at you and stop thinking so much about his horses.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We might as well start a fire.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Go ahead.  Get in training for the pioneer life. I'm finding the nearest body of water and climbing into it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Give it back to him. We're leavin'.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Maybe you are. I'm not.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: -- Gaslights and a dance floor and a big bar. Cash registers with bells and a couple of boys with armbands just to keep 'em ringing. What do you think of that?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Sounds fine. Only that isn't how it's going to be.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I'm sure of this. But not of you.  You won't open any joint. I've been watching you change. You're mad now and you think you can change back. But you can't. You'll end up making beds in a boarding house.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That's it then.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Mary, Honey. I talked too much, like always -- he thinks you told Elaine the things I told her.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't care what he thinks.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: How do you know who we are?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Everybody knows --

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: Who brought you here?

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: You said somebody was comin' back -- who's comin' back?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Stop it --

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Clay Phillips.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: Where is he?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Up the trail.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: How far up the trail?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I don't know -- I don't know.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: We got to get movin'.

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: Because there's a man I want to see.

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: He can wait. Let's stay here until morning.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: I said let's go.

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: One night more won't matter. Your friend'll be there. Anyway I don't think so much of the idea of prowling around his ranch. He knows you're out so he ain't going to sit still for it.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: I said I had a guy to see and I'm going to see him.

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: We got company. Female company.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: Yeah, we sure have.

turns.speaker: WYATT
turns.text: Why, yes. They're all I need...

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: Mine's gone lame. Take a look at him.

turns.speaker: WYATT
turns.text: He dropped a shoe. You shouldn't be ridin' him.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: Put on another one.

turns.speaker: WYATT
turns.text: That won't help the stone bruise. You ain't been around horses much, looks like.

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: Will you quit gabbin' and do what you're told.

turns.speaker: WYATT
turns.text: What are you doin' --

turns.speaker: LEDNOV
turns.text: Lookin' around.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Pleased to meet you, ma'am.  We found your trunk. Were you doin' the driven'?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I was at first. Then I was hanging on.  Are you going far?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Is that your kind of reading, Steve?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I can't read, Ma'am. I just look at the pictures.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Your brother's always looked after you, hasn't he?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Since I can remember, Ma'am.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But he just never troubled to have you get any schooling?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: It wasn't Clay's fault. We've been moving around most all the time -- mebbe when we get the ranch and stay in one place I can learn my letters then --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't you even know your letters?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Would you like to learn them?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I sure would.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Maybe I could start you out.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: That'd be swell.  You know, you're an awful lot different than I thought you'd be.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: You're so nice.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Did someone say I wasn't nice?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Oh no. Nobody said nothing to me. Only I got the idea that -- well Clay and me used to be walking through town and there was your place and through the window I could see you dancing, but Clay always took me over to the other side of the street.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Good night, Miss Wells.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Good night, Steve.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Gee, I can't.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why not? You went farther than that last time.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I'm too old for it, Miss Wells... That's for little kids.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't be silly... Nobody's too old to learn.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Okay. A-B-C -- D-E-F -- G-H-I --

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Aren't we stayin'?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No. We're not stayin' --

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What comes after Z?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That's the end of the line.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Then I know my alphabet.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: From A to Z. All you have to do now is figure out what they mean put together in words.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: And that's tough, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Without someone to teach you, it's tough.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: -- and even if I do learn to read, what use'll it be? I'm goin' to live on a ranch!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: There's plenty of use for reading -- you'll see.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: U-n-i-c-o-r-n-... What in heck's that?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Unicorn -- a kind of animal --

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: What do they look like?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Hmmm... sort of like a horse -- with a horn in the center of its forehead.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Horses with horns! Huh! Do we have 'em in Nevada?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: How about California?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Would they be good to eat?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Kind of tough, I guess... But you're not liable to hunt them -- I don't think there's any alive now, anyways -- and I'm not sure but I don't think there ever were...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Then if they wasn't alive, how can they be an animal?...

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: An' if you can't hunt 'em and even if you could they'd be tough, what's the use of knowin' how to spell them?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You don't read to fill your stomach... Poetry, for instance. All the poems in the world wouldn't fill you half as much as a bowl of eatmeal -- but they make you feel good.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I feel good anyways.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well, Steve?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Now I know what a unicorn is, what do we do next?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Nobody's gonna catch him sleeping. Don't worry about him.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, I wasn't worrying.  I saw him saddling up and thought he was ready to leave.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Sometimes not knowin' how to read has its points. You can't read books so you look at people and figure 'em out.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: And you've got me all figured out?

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Like when you were standin' there looking after Clay. I knew right off what you were thinking. Because I've been watching you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You were supposed to be reading words.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I was doin' both. Here.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Don't pay any attention to him. That's his way and I've found he's sure easy to get along with. I don't recollect him havin' hit me more'n a couple of times and I guess I had it comin'.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But you're his brother.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: He'll treat his wife just as good. Maybe better. Ever see him use a bull snake on the mules like other wranglers?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: She was only teasin'.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Oh, sure.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Let me do that.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: For the last ten miles I've been trying to figure out how to sleep sitting up. I'm getting to the point where I don't think there's any place named Sonora.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: It's a long ways yet.  I figure we ought to camp. She's tired.
